title: 111_hr2240
content: Section 1 introduces a nonrefundable credit for mentoring and housing young adults under a new section 25E in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The new section 25E in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows a $1,000 tax credit for qualified mentors for each qualifying mentored individual. Limitations include proration for individuals reaching age 18 or 21 during the taxable year and a limitation based on the amount of tax. The tax credit for qualified mentors under section 25E is limited based on the regular tax liability and other credits allowable for the taxable year. A qualified mentor is defined as an individual over 21 certified by a mentoring agency. The tax credit for qualified mentors under section 25E is limited based on the regular tax liability and other credits allowable for the taxable year. A qualified mentor is defined as an individual over 21 certified by a mentoring agency, who provides mentoring services to a qualifying mentored individual in compliance with mentoring requirements. The mentoring relationship involves monthly meetings and activities. A qualifying mentored individual is someone over 18 years old. The tax credit for qualified mentors under section 25E is limited based on the regular tax liability and other credits allowable for the taxable year. A qualified mentor is an individual over 21 who provides mentoring services to a qualifying mentored individual. The mentored individual must be over 18, placed by an authorized agency or court, and share the same principal place of abode with the taxpayer for more than half of the taxable year. The taxpayer must include the name and taxpayer identification number of the mentored individual on their tax return to claim the credit. The tax credit under section 25E is only allowable for a full taxable year, except in cases of a taxpayer's death. Various sections of the tax code are amended to include references to section 25E. Section 30B, 30D, and the table of sections in the tax code are amended to include references to section 25E. Section 25E introduces mentoring and housing for young adults, with amendments applying to taxable years after the enactment of the Act.
